# Law Firm Job Hunting And Recruiting In The Age Of COVID-19
## Here are five ways in which job searching and recruiting have changed in the past three months.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onMay 29, 2020 at 5:17 PMMay 29, 2020 at 5:22 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/law-firm-job-hunting-and-recruiting-in-the-age-of-covid-19/&text=Law%20Firm%20Job%20Hunting%20And%20Recruiting%20In%20The%20Age%20Of%20COVID-19)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/law-firm-job-hunting-and-recruiting-in-the-age-of-covid-19/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/law-firm-job-hunting-and-recruiting-in-the-age-of-covid-19/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(via Getty Images)

It’s amazing how much can change in three short months. Over the course of your lifetime, can you pick out a three-month period in which your life changed as much as it has between March 1 and June 1? Speaking for myself, I can’t.

So many things are dramatically different as a result of the coronavirus pandemic — many things for the [worse](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/layoffs/), but at least a few for the [better](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/what-good-might-come-out-of-the-coronavirus-crisis/?rf=1). Law firm job hunting and recruiting are no exceptions.

Here are five ways in which job searching and recruiting have changed in the past three months:

1. There are far fewer jobs out there.

Let’s start with the obvious. In the economy writ large, we went from almost full employment in March to a projected [20 percent unemployment](https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/05/28/coronavirus-2-1-m-file-unemployment-benefits-amid-covid-19/5265672002/) for May (when the labor statistics come out for this month). The legal sector has not been immune, losing an estimated [64,000 jobs](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/05/08/legal-industry-shed-64000-jobs-in-april-as-layoffs-and-furloughs-spread/) in April alone.

Large law firms have also retrenched, going from eagerly seeking laterals to furloughing or laying off lawyers and staff. If you’re receiving many fewer emails or calls from recruiters, don’t be offended or surprised; it’s not you, it’s the firms. A fair number of firms have implemented hiring freezes or are focusing on only high-priority searches.

2. Video interviewing: it is now, officially, “a thing.”

In the past, video interviewing over Zoom, Skype, or similar tools was the exception rather than the rule. For lawyers working abroad who wanted to return to the U.S., for example, video interviews were not uncommon, especially in the early or screening stages.

Now, of course, video interviewing is pretty much the only way interviewing takes place, thanks to the restrictions imposed to halt or slow the spread of coronavirus. And you know what? It has been fine. Speaking for myself, I have a fair number of candidates going through remote interviews right now, and nobody has had a snafu yet (knock wood).

Law firms and candidates are getting increasingly comfortable with remote interviewing. In fact, I’ve already had one candidate who was interviewed, hired, and onboarded remotely. He has been working for his new firm since late March, but he has yet to set foot in the firm’s physical offices.

The current crisis represents an excellent opportunity for firms that are willing to buck tradition and recruit remotely. These firms can scoop up top talent, while more conservative competitors sit on their hands.

3. It’s all (or mostly) about the partners.

Yes, there’s some activity in the associate market, but make no mistake: the market isn’t what it was like back in March. The associate space is much, much quieter, especially in previously booming transactional practices like M&A.

But partner recruiting remains robust, much as it did during the Great Recession. When the pie is shrinking, the way for firms to survive (or thrive) is by grabbing a larger slice of that shrinking pie. So firms are seeking out partners with big books of business, to help them grow revenue during these challenging times.

And partners are also quite willing to look around. In working on a few recent searches, I’ve found that partners at firms that have cut their compensation or that seem financially unstable are especially receptive to outreach these days.

4. Standards are higher.

This isn’t surprising. Video interviews, even if more common, aren’t the firms’ preferred way of recruiting — so if they are willing to go to the trouble of interviewing someone, that someone tends to be very impressive (or the need tends to be very dire). In a hot market, so-so candidates can get traction for various reasons, such as being in a coveted practice area. That’s not true today (yes, even for bankruptcy).

5. Firms want exactly what they want.

For the relatively few searches that are open, the firms want exactly what’s specified. In better markets, there’s usually some flexibility as to things like class year or practice area. But in this market, a buyer’s market in terms of legal talent, the firms are in firmly in control. And they’re taking the [Burger King approach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Burger_King_ad_programs): they’ll have it their way, thank you very much.

These are just very general observations about the Biglaw job market today. For more detailed discussion, please join me on Tuesday, June 2, at 2:30 p.m. EDT/11:30 a.m. PDT, for a free webinar, [Law Firm Recruiting During COVID-19](https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_LZTbmpfaR9SNeFvyShDQ0w). I’ll moderate a panel featuring three of my Lateral Link colleagues: [Gloria Sandrino](https://www.laterallink.com/team/gloria-sandrino/), who heads our partner practice; [Zach Sandberg](https://www.laterallink.com/team/zach-sandberg/), who will discuss associate recruiting; and [Craig Brown](https://www.laterallink.com/team/craig-brown/), a longtime leader in the world of temporary placements. We hope to “see” you then!

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s](http://laterallink.com/) team of expert contributors. David Lat is a managing director in the New York office, where he focuses on placing top associates, partners, and partner groups into preeminent law firms around the country.

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. # The Ranks Of Biglaw Partnership Are Shrinking
## Your chances of making partner are dropping.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 25, 2018 at 12:02 PMApril 25, 2018 at 11:14 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-ranks-of-biglaw-partnership-are-shrinking/&text=The%20Ranks%20Of%20Biglaw%20Partnership%20Are%20Shrinking)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-ranks-of-biglaw-partnership-are-shrinking/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-ranks-of-biglaw-partnership-are-shrinking/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
At the biggest of the Biglaw firms there’s a disturbing trend afoot — well, disturbing if you still hold out the faint hope of one day making partner at a Biglaw shop — the percentage of partners at the best firms is steadily decreasing. That’s according to data [collected by Law360](https://www.law360.com/legalindustry/articles/1032555/why-biglaw-s-partnerships-are-shrinking) at 64 of the 100 biggest 100 firms.

Overall, the partnership numbers in 2013 went from 42.2 percent of lawyer headcount to 40.8 percent by 2017.

There are even 16 elite firms where the partnership clocks in at under 25 percent of headcount.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Why are [#BigLaw](https://twitter.com/hashtag/BigLaw?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) partnerships shrinking? [https://t.co/relvDADhmZ](https://t.co/relvDADhmZ) [pic.twitter.com/eRJ029dzxB](https://t.co/eRJ029dzxB)

— Law360 (@Law360) [April 23, 2018](https://twitter.com/Law360/status/988494036905398274?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

And, as with most Biglaw decisions it probably has something to do with money  As William Henderson, a professor at Indiana University Maurer School of Law, told Law360:

“A smaller number of partners means a fewer number of slices that need to be cut up when you divide the profit pool.”

Ropes & Gray managing partner, David Chapin, also says that Biglaw is naturally conservative and that cautious nature plays a role:

“It’s fair to say that firms in general, and we’re no exception, are being more cautious about advancing people into the equity partner ranks,” Chapin said. “All firms have been, and we have been, more judicious in that respect.”

It also might be that more attorneys are opting out of the partnership hunt. Peter Johnson of Law Practice Consultants says lawyers instead prefer the world of in-house:

“The stigma about leaving a large law firm to go someplace else is not what it used to be… Going in-house used to be ‘going out to pasture.’ Now it’s a preferred job for many.”

Let’s hope that people who find themselves shut out of partnership opportunities find other rewarding work.

# WOW!!! Davis Polk Raises The Bar On Bonuses
## This is going to put a lot of pressure on the market.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 15, 2020 at 2:38 PMSeptember 17, 2020 at 12:27 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/&text=WOW!!!%20Davis%20Polk%20Raises%20The%20Bar%20On%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
That cheering you hear is coming from the offices of Davis Polk, where associates were just handed a cascade of good news beginning with some special bonuses. Remember when we were [applauding Cooley LLP for giving senior associates $7,500](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cooley-bonuses/)? Well, Davis Polk decided to blow up that scale like they were making a Michael Bay movie.

Domestic associates in good standing will be receiving special Fall bonuses in recognition of their hard work throughout [gestures wildly at everything]. Here’s what we’re looking at:

- Class of 2019: $7,500
- Class of 2018: $10,000
- Class of 2017: $20,000
- Class of 2016: $27,500
- Class of 2015: $32,500
- Class of 2014: $37,000
- Class of 2013: $40,000
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Yowza.

International associates will receive separate case-by-case bonuses.

But that’s not the end of the good news. The message to associates also assured them that these bonuses are NOT replacements for the traditional year-end bonuses and that the firm expects to be handing those out on schedule too. Oh, and the firm expects that these annual bonuses “will not be lower than those paid out in 2019.”

That would mean that in the worst case, a first-year associate is going to take home $22,500 in bonuses in a year of unprecedented economic upheaval. Biglaw firms tend to stick together when it comes to bonuses. DPW just put a lot of pressure on its peers to match.

# Say Hello To The Newest Biglaw Perk: Remote Working Benefits
## Will your firm be able to keep up with the market?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 16, 2021 at 3:15 PMJuly 16, 2021 at 4:13 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/say-hello-to-the-newst-biglaw-perk-remote-working-benefits/&text=Say%20Hello%20To%20The%20Newest%20Biglaw%20Perk:%20Remote%20Working%20Benefits)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/say-hello-to-the-newst-biglaw-perk-remote-working-benefits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/say-hello-to-the-newst-biglaw-perk-remote-working-benefits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s not just altruism. It’s economics. To the extent that law firm leaders start to recognize that part of the competitive offering, from associates to partners, and associates to business professionals, is the remote working policy, they’re going to embed somewhere in their policy some sustainable flexibility.

— Tim Corcoran, a law firm consultant who specializes in compensation issues, commenting on the fact that top law firms will [need to start offering more and more flexibility as a fringe benefit](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/07/15/as-law-firms-plan-office-returns-whole-remote-weeks-may-become-newest-benefit/) of sorts to keep up with the market.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law  
[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# Everyone Should Have Black Friday Off
## Don't be a Grinch. It just makes more sense in most cases.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onNovember 29, 2023 at 11:48 AMNovember 29, 2023 at 12:03 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/everyone-should-have-black-friday-off/&text=Everyone%20Should%20Have%20Black%20Friday%20Off)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/everyone-should-have-black-friday-off/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/everyone-should-have-black-friday-off/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Everyone in the legal profession understands that people should not be expected to perform work on certain holidays. Christmas and New Year’s Day are definitely two such holidays. Thanksgiving, which most of us recently celebrated, is another holiday when people are generally not expected to be billing hours. The day after Thanksgiving, which many people now call Black Friday, should also be a day when legal professionals and others should have off from work since individuals usually have obligations that reasonably prevent them from working.

I always assumed that Black Friday was some kind of established holiday since I was used to taking time off during it. However, Black Friday is not a bank holiday for many financial institutions. In addition, the mail is delivered during Black Friday. It does look like the stock market only has a partial day on Black Friday, which must be a welcome treat for financial professionals.

Many law firms do (officially or unofficially) recognize Black Friday as time off for attorneys and staff. I worked at law firms which explicitly list Black Friday as a time when the office would be closed. I also worked at law firms that did not explicitly list Black Friday as a holiday, but people were not expected to show up to the office nor to perform work related to their jobs.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
However, some lawyers definitely work on Black Friday. This past Black Friday was pretty busy for my law practice. As a self-employed lawyer, I do not at all mind working on Black Friday, since the flexibility of being self-employed is more than worth needing to work during periods when other lawyers might have off. But I noticed that some of my counterparts who work at law firms both big and small were working during Black Friday. Some of the tasks these attorneys completed on Black Friday could have definitely waited until Monday, when most people returned to work after the Thanksgiving holiday.

Of course, some attorneys do not mind working over times that attorneys usually have off. Lawyers might need to bill extra hours before the end of the year to meet requirements or earn a bonus. Even when I worked at a law firm that had Black Friday off, I did not mind billing hours over the Thanksgiving weekend to make sure I qualified for a larger bonus by the end of the year.

However, law firm managers should rarely require people to work on Black Friday if there are no emergent matters that require attention. The work-life balance has degraded in recent years since the work-from-home revolution has blended the lines between everyone’s work and personal life. Thanksgiving weekend is usually a time when people reconnect with family and friends in ways that might not be possible during other parts of the year. Moreover, many people travel during Thanksgiving to be with friends and family, and it is unfair to require these individual to perform work when they might not be able to efficiently complete work tasks.

Also, it is highly problematic to require attorneys and staff to perform work on a day that is between a holiday and a weekend. I think I wrote about this topic before, but generally if a holiday falls on a Tuesday or a Thursday, it is generous for employers to give workers the extra day off so they connect the holiday with the weekend to have a longer time off. It is hard to imagine that employees can be very useful if they just celebrated Thanksgiving and have the weekend to look forward to, so it usually make sense to just give workers time off for Black Friday.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
In any case, if law firms have not explicitly added Black Friday to their list of recognized days off, they definitely should. Cutting workers a break over Black Friday helps lawyers and staff enjoy their Thanksgiving and helps preserve the work-life balance that has been under attack in recent years.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothman.law/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # The Biglaw Layoffs Are Far From Over
## It's highly likely that another firm will soon announce a reduction in force. But which one?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 16, 2023 at 3:44 PMJune 16, 2023 at 12:59 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biglaw-layoffs-are-far-from-over/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Layoffs%20Are%20Far%20From%20Over)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biglaw-layoffs-are-far-from-over/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biglaw-layoffs-are-far-from-over/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

These are probably not the last reductions in force that we’re going to see.

— [Kate Reder Sheikh](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/kate-reder-sheikh), a California legal recruiter for Major, Lindsey & Africa, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/reed-smith-cuts-50-lawyers-and-staff-as-big-law-layoffs-continue) in the wake of [Reed Smith’s reduction in force](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/another-top-50-am-law-firm-cuts-its-global-work-force/). The firm is just the latest to cut jobs in the wake of a slowdown in demand and overcapacity among their ranks due to a lack of attrition, or “bloated payrolls,” as Reder Sheikh put it.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Supreme Court Intervenes In Mystery Mueller Filing
## It's the first challenge to Mueller's authority.
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onDecember 24, 2018 at 11:59 AMDecember 26, 2018 at 11:48 AM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/supreme-court-intervenes-in-mystery-mueller-filing/&text=Supreme%20Court%20Intervenes%20In%20Mystery%20Mueller%20Filing)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/supreme-court-intervenes-in-mystery-mueller-filing/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/supreme-court-intervenes-in-mystery-mueller-filing/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Chief Justice Roberts would like you to simmer down. (Nati Harnik/AP)

In what’s shaping up to be the first Supreme Court challenge involving the Mueller investigation, Chief Justice John Roberts stepped in to stay a D.C. Circuit ruling holding a foreign company in contempt of the Mueller grand jury.

Apparently, Mueller is seeking information from corporation in “Country A,” and that corporation claims immunity from the Mueller probe under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Last week, the lower court agreed with Mueller. The D.C. Circuit found that the case falls within an exception to the Act for activities that have a “direct effect” on the United States.

Clearly, the corporation here is a state-owned bank or financial institution. Mueller is following the money, whether that money is locked up in Russia or Saudi Arabia or wherever.

Over the weekend, the Supreme Court decided to get involved. [From Howe on the Court](http://amylhowe.com/2018/12/22/justices-asked-to-intervene-in-grand-jury-dispute/):

On Sunday evening, Chief Justice John Roberts temporarily blocked the district court’s order requiring the foreign corporation to comply with the grand jury subpoena or pay penalties. In a brief order, the chief justice directed the government to respond by noon on December 31 and indicated that the district court’s order would remain on hold until the government’s response is filed and either he or the full court takes additional action.

Folks, the Mueller probe isn’t going to be finished any time soon. Oh, Trump might find an attorney general to unnaturally end the investigation in order to protect himself, but the investigation doesn’t look to be “wrapping up.”

If the Supreme Court compels the foreign corporation to answer the subpoena, who knows what other crimes might be uncovered.

# Work Perk Alert: Are Music Rooms The Next Big Thing For Biglaw Firms?
## This Biglaw firm is making it easier for attorneys to rock to the beat during their work days thanks to its new music room.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 22, 2024 at 2:14 PMApril 22, 2024 at 1:53 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/work-perk-alert-are-music-rooms-the-next-big-thing-for-biglaw-firms/&text=Work%20Perk%20Alert:%20Are%20Music%20Rooms%20The%20Next%20Big%20Thing%20For%20Biglaw%20Firms?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/work-perk-alert-are-music-rooms-the-next-big-thing-for-biglaw-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/work-perk-alert-are-music-rooms-the-next-big-thing-for-biglaw-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms are doing all they can to make the return to the office sound more appealing to attorneys, and one firm seems to be hitting all of the right notes with one of the work perks that it’s currently offering.

Mayer Brown — a firm that brought in $1,908,000,000 gross revenue in 2023, putting it at No. 23 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking — is staying in rhythm with the times by paying attention to its office culture. The firm recently added a brand new music room to its Charlotte outpost. [Law.com](https://www.law.com/2024/04/19/the-law-firm-disrupted-for-office-attendance-is-music-a-new-carrot/) has additional details:

Instead of [adding] one more conference room, they asked the question, “What could appeal to everyone, and bring younger and older generations together?”

The answer: a music room. Start with a lounge space—warm tones, comfortable furniture—but outfit it with a high-end record player and excellent speakers. And stock it with a pile of records, a figure that’s up to 200 now, along with books on music. (There’s also a TV in the mix.) And in a twist on traditional activities for summer associates, the Charlotte team gets to make a trip to a local record store to pick out a fresh stack of vinyl for the collection.

Personnel in the Charlotte office put the room to use in a variety of ways, according to [managing partner Eric] Reilly. Several groups have monthly meetings there, with music in the background. Others filter in later in the day, looking for a change in pace. And it works as a place to meet clients and break the ice.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
“It’s able to provide a little bit of relaxation in the sometimes chaotic workday of a transactional law practice, where things can tend to be very fast-paced and stressful,” Reilly told Law.com. “Having a place to unwind and collect your thoughts and reflect throughout the day, even for a few minutes, has been helpful.”

Congratulations to Mayer Brown for its willingness to put its attorneys’ happiness first with this harmonious new offering. By staying in tune with its culture like this, the firm is making it a lot easier for employees to feel truly valued.

What does the culture at your law firm look like? We’d love to profile what life looks like at your firm. Please get in touch with us — via text (646-820-8477) or [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Culture) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Culture”) — and let us know.

# Bill, Baby, Bill ... But Don't Forget To Enter Your Time -- Or Else!
## Don't let your bonus suffer -- enter your time ASAP.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 22, 2023 at 2:14 PMAugust 22, 2023 at 2:09 PM
19
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/bill-baby-bill-but-dont-forget-to-enter-your-time-or-else/&text=Bill,%20Baby,%20Bill%20…%20But%20Don’t%20Forget%20To%20Enter%20Your%20Time%20—%20Or%20Else!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/bill-baby-bill-but-dont-forget-to-enter-your-time-or-else/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/bill-baby-bill-but-dont-forget-to-enter-your-time-or-else/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

I practiced law for nearly 15 years and hated timesheets as much as the next person. But it’s just critical it be done on a daily basis. So I’m not surprised law firms are being more aggressive in requiring it and penalizing people, especially in this associate market, which has shifted. Now, they might not have done it two years ago, where it was a seller’s market. But now the shoe is on the other foot.

Even if it makes a 1% difference in revenue or collections or profitability—when you’re looking at firms generating billions of dollars, that’s a lot of money. So yeah, I think in tougher times, they want people to really focus on the basics. And people might also have more time to focus on the basics because it’s not as crazy as it was in 2021.

— [Jeffrey Lowe](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeffrey-lowe-b64a886/), founder and managing partner of advisory firm Jeffrey Lowe Partners, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/08/22/in-current-market-billing-discipline-more-critical-than-ever/) on the reason why entering time is “more critical than ever,” especially in a market like this one. Lowe’s critical commentary comes in the wake of [Sidley Austin threatening to dock year-end bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/sidley-docks-bonus-late-timesheets/) by up to 50% if attorneys’ billable time is consistently entered late.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Overhired, And Now Associates And Staff Are Paying The Price
## Is overhiring responsible for the latest Biglaw layoffs? It's very likely.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 18, 2023 at 10:42 AMMay 18, 2023 at 10:33 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-dechert-overhiring-layoffs/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Overhired,%20And%20Now%20Associates%20And%20Staff%20Are%20Paying%20The%20Price)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-dechert-overhiring-layoffs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-dechert-overhiring-layoffs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms were thrilled to hire as many associates and business professionals as they could during the booming “post”-pandemic business years, but now that demand has cooled significantly, layoffs meant to “right-size” head count have spread across the industry.

Last week, Dechert — a firm that brought in $1,288,692,000 gross revenue in 2022 (down 3.94% from 2021), putting it at No. 36 in the most recent Am Law 100 — announced a [global reduction in force](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/am-law-top-50-firm-begins-reduction-in-force-will-cut-5-of-global-workforce/), cutting 5% of the firm’s workforce, including attorneys and business professionals. In total, these layoffs impacted 55 lawyers and 43 business professionals.

But what was behind the firm’s sudden overcapacity? A source tells the American Lawyer that it was very likely a case of overhiring.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Dechert appears to have been caught up in a boom-and-bust hiring cycle, with the private equity and finance ranks in particular swelling to meet rising demand and then leaving the firm with overcapacity concerns.

One source with knowledge of the firm attributed the cuts to overhiring. After a surge in demand that led many law firms like Dechert to hire associates beyond the normal scope of its hiring pool, “demand is returning to normal or maybe worse than normal, depending on how deep the recession goes,” the source said.

According to Am Law, Dechert’s 5% global cut will return its workforce to just around its 2021 staffing levels. At the end of 2021, the firm had 1,815 employees, and these layoffs will bring the firm’s personnel count to 1,798. How incredibly convenient!

Did your firm overhire in 2021 and 2022? Are you expecting layoffs to occur in the near future that will “right-size” the firm? Please don’t hesitate to reach out to us by email at  [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) or by sending a text message to (646) 820-8477.

# Biglaw's 'Bank' Of Remote Days Will Only Make Associates More Frustrated About Having To Work From The Office
## They're already working all the time -- why does it matter where they work?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 17, 2023 at 3:46 PMJuly 17, 2023 at 2:47 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaws-bank-of-remote-days-will-only-make-associates-more-frustrated-about-having-to-work-from-the-office/&text=Biglaw’s%20‘Bank’%20Of%20Remote%20Days%20Will%20Only%20Make%20Associates%20More%20Frustrated%20About%20Having%20To%20Work%20From%20The%20Office)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaws-bank-of-remote-days-will-only-make-associates-more-frustrated-about-having-to-work-from-the-office/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaws-bank-of-remote-days-will-only-make-associates-more-frustrated-about-having-to-work-from-the-office/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

The law at the Am Law 200 level is really a 24/7 position. So I think that’s why associates get frustrated with the whole office policy to begin with. [It’s a difficult message for associates to hear], ‘You didn’t do enough’ or ‘It’s not enough that you’re on the grid 24/7. You need to be physically where we need you to be.’ I think that’s hard for them to swallow.

— [Michelle Fivel](https://www.hhflegalsearch.com/michelle-fivel), a partner and co-founder of the legal recruiting firm Hatch Henderson Fivel, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/07/17/with-big-law-marching-to-most-days-in-office-some-bank-remote-days/) on the latest push for associates to return to the office four days a week, with a “bank” of remote days available. Fivel went on to say these “banks” could help “lessen the blow” of needing to be in the office more often than not, but that it likely wouldn’t affect things from a recruiting perspective. “It’s a factor that people would consider, but it would be a rare situation that it would be make or break,” she said. “There are so many factors that come into play. I think it’s a plus in the firm’s column, but I don’t think it’s going to be enough.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# It's Special Bonus Time At This Major West Coast Biglaw Leader
## Big-time bonus money goes nationwide!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 29, 2021 at 12:48 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/wilson-sonsini-special-bonus-2021/&text=It’s%20Special%20Bonus%20Time%20At%20This%20Major%20West%20Coast%20Biglaw%20Leader)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/wilson-sonsini-special-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/wilson-sonsini-special-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw special bonuses are being handed out across the country, and other firms better start paying attention, because the latest firm to hand out oodles of money to associates is a major West Coast leader.

Wilson Sonsini associates and counsel received great news this morning (this afternoon, on the East Coast) when a memo related to their forthcoming big-time bonuses hit their inboxes. This is what the special bonuses look like at WSGR (full memo on the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/wilson-sonsini-special-bonus-2021/2/)):



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Associates and of counsel who are on track to bill at least 1950 bonus-eligible hours in 2021 will receive payouts based on year-to-date hours billed as of May 31 and August 31, and make-up payments will be available. It’s also worth noting here that Wilson Sonsini is providing two weeks of well-being time off, 40 hours of which are billable and bonus eligible. More firms should get on board with billable vacations.

Congratulations to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/wilson-sonsini-special-bonus-2021/2/) to see the full memo from Wilson Sonsini.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# This Is What Happens When You Try To Scam A Biglaw Firm
## This was entirely predictable.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 2, 2023 at 2:18 PMNovember 2, 2023 at 1:50 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-is-what-happens-when-you-try-to-scam-a-biglaw-firm/&text=This%20Is%20What%20Happens%20When%20You%20Try%20To%20Scam%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-is-what-happens-when-you-try-to-scam-a-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-is-what-happens-when-you-try-to-scam-a-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If I were an online scammer — I’m not, but if I were — I’m not sure I’d be targeting a major Biglaw firm. Sure, lawyers have a well-earned reputation as luddites — or at least behind the ball on tech issues, which certainly weighs in favor of them as targets. But on the other, perhaps more relevant hand, why poke a bear that has unlimited elite legal resources to throw at you?

Latham & Watkins is certainly one of those Biglaw firms with unlimited legal resources that doesn’t take too kindly to entities that try to scam its clients using the name of one of their partners. This week, the firm filed a lawsuit against domain names that are trying to impersonate Latham.

As per [Law.com:](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/11/01/latham-sues-domain-names-after-fraudsters-impersonated-partner-to-divert-payments/)

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Per the complaint, the scheme began in April when the scammer registered a handful of domains that began with “LW,” a reference to Latham’s genuine domain of LW.com. Using 38 variants that included “LW-France.com” and “LW-Frn.com,” the unknown party attempted to impersonate Paris-based partner Alexandra Bigot.

“The scammer would then email third parties to ‘remind’ them of unpaid invoices,” the complaint stated. “The scammer even included vague threats to the third-party victims, suggesting that they ‘resolve it today to avoid other accusations.’”

Fortunately, as the complaint notes, Latham’s clients didn’t so much fall for the scam, as alert Bigot her name was being used in the scheme.

It seems unlikely that attempted scammers will come forward to defend the lawsuit, so a default judgment seems in the cards. Which… was always the most likely way this was going to end.

# This Biglaw Firm's Profits Per Equity Partner Sure Took A Hit
## Quite the change from last year.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 6, 2019 at 4:16 PMMay 6, 2019 at 1:21 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firms-profits-per-equity-partner-sure-took-a-hit/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Profits%20Per%20Equity%20Partner%20Sure%20Took%20A%20Hit)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firms-profits-per-equity-partner-sure-took-a-hit/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/this-biglaw-firms-profits-per-equity-partner-sure-took-a-hit/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
According to data collected for the 2019 Am Law 100, which Am Law 100 firm saw the largest decrease in profits per equity partner in 2018 over 2017?

Hint: The firm’s PEP went down 9.6 percent.

See the answer on the next page.

# Biglaw Firm Takes Harsh Stance On Productivity This Year
## Bill your hours or you won't be considered for a bonus.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 1, 2020 at 1:43 PMOctober 2, 2020 at 9:53 AM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/biglaw-firm-takes-harsh-stance-on-productivity-this-year/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Takes%20Harsh%20Stance%20On%20Productivity%20This%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/biglaw-firm-takes-harsh-stance-on-productivity-this-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/biglaw-firm-takes-harsh-stance-on-productivity-this-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Oof, 2020, what a year! Amirite? I know, we still have three months left in this interminable year, but still, we know it’s been a doozy of a year. But however long 2020 has seemed, that hasn’t always translated into a boon of billable hours for Biglaw associates.

The pandemic has exploded everyone’s personal obligations and whether stymied by remote learning, illness of themselves or a loved one, the emotional turmoil of social injustice, or depression, lots of excellent attorneys have found it challenging to bill at pre-pandemic levels. And that’s assuming the hours are even there in the first place. With the economic downturn that accompanied the pandemic, if an associate is ready and able to work, sometimes the hours just aren’t there. Whether it’s particular practice groups that have taken a slump, clients that are particularly hard hit, or [partners hoarding the hours](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/associates-left-searching-for-billable-hours-after-partners-take-them-all/), sometimes its more about the firm’s business model than anything an associate did wrong.

So, you might think that, given all these factors, if a Biglaw firm has billing thresholds to get year-end bonuses, they might loosen up some of those requirements in order to retain the best and brightest during this trying time — after all, not every firm even has these strict requirements. Well, when it comes to Arnold & Porter, welp, you’d be wrong.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Earlier this week, an email was sent out from firm leadership codifying a statement made in a town hall. The firm is encouraging associates to send in “hours messages” as part of their annual review process, for anyone who failed to hit the expected 2,000 hours threshold. Which, so far, so good. With all that 2020’s been, some consideration is warranted. But then the email goes on to explain that statement will only go towards whether an associate is still considered in good standing and the hours statement “will not impact bonus eligibility for 2020. The hours thresholds for bonus consideration remain unchanged.”

Yikes. I mean I guess it’s a step in the right direction that the firm won’t put an associate on a performance improvement plan or something just because they only managed to bill 1,800 hours in this crazy year, but I guess there’s a limit to Biglaw’s compassion.

And 2,000 hours is just nonnegotiable.

Read the full email below (click to enlarge).

# Biglaw Firm Announces Full Retroactive Salary Restorations For All, Plus Some Bonus News
## This is fantastic news.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 12, 2020 at 12:43 PMNovember 12, 2020 at 12:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/biglaw-firm-announces-full-retroactive-salary-restorations-for-all-plus-some-bonus-news/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20Full%20Retroactive%20Salary%20Restorations%20For%20All,%20Plus%20Some%20Bonus%20News)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/biglaw-firm-announces-full-retroactive-salary-restorations-for-all-plus-some-bonus-news/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/biglaw-firm-announces-full-retroactive-salary-restorations-for-all-plus-some-bonus-news/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As 2020 draws to a close and holiday season quickly approaches, more and more Biglaw firms are announcing good news (or as good of news as can be expected considering they’re still doing business amid the never-ending coronavirus crisis).

Today, we have news from Stoel Rives, a firm that came in 132nd place in the most recent Am Law 200 rankings, with $236,541,000 in gross revenue in 2019. Back in October, the firm announced that it would be [eliminating all of its pandemic-related austerity measures](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/biglaw-firm-announces-complete-rollback-of-covid-austerity-measures/) and prospectively restoring base pay for all attorneys and staff members. Earlier this week, Melissa Jones, the managing partner of Stoel Rives, sent a memo to all employees at the firm detailing plans to retroactively restore base compensation for attorneys. On top of that, Jones announced some bonus news:

[T]he [Executive Committee] confirmed that we will leave in place the bonus pools for all staff (including paralegals), associates, of counsel and staff attorneys as reflected in our 2020 budget.

The Practice Management Committee is meeting soon to allocate the bonus pool for associates, of counsel, and staff attorneys. We anticipate that bonus decisions will be communicated in early/mid-December, and that bonuses will be paid no later than Friday, December 18.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Associates are thriled by the news, and one source gushed, “Everyone is so happy under Melissa Jones’s leadership!” Payments to restore base compensation will be made by the end of November. Congratulations to everyone at the firm. Now that [bonus season has officially started](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/breaking-biglaw-bonus-season-comes-early-and-no-its-not-cravath/), we hope you get some good news soon.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries or restoring previous cuts, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Nothin' Says Lovin' Like $180K In Your Paycheck
## After making a lot of attorneys mad, this firm's finally coughed up the cash.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 24, 2016 at 3:11 PMJune 24, 2016 at 4:15 PM
9
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/nothin-says-lovin-like-180k-in-your-paycheck/&text=Nothin’%20Says%20Lovin’%20Like%20$180K%20In%20Your%20Paycheck)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/nothin-says-lovin-like-180k-in-your-paycheck/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/nothin-says-lovin-like-180k-in-your-paycheck/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As the title suggests, the Doughboys and girls over at Pillsbury have matched the Cravath scale. From what we’ve heard there’s no memo (UPDATE: There is a memo… [and it’s here](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/nothin-says-lovin-like-180k-in-your-paycheck/2/)), but they’ve agreed to match the Cravath scale across all of their U.S. offices. UPDATE: The top end of the scale is $315K.

And Pillsbury has a LOT of domestic offices. In addition to the obvious locales like New York and D.C., the firm has offices in Los Angeles, Austin, Houston, Nashville, Northern Virginia, Sacramento, San Diego (two offices), San Francisco, and Silicon Valley. The firm also has a Palm Beach office, but does not appear to have any associates there.

Pillsbury just missed the cut of [our last “irate associates” post](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/angry-associates-ask-wheres-my-money/), announcing their raises less than 2 minutes before the post was slated to go public. To let the firm in on exactly how testy its associates had been before this announcement, let’s share what they were thinking:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
If I were one of our T14 summer associates I would seriously be looking at 3L OCI options. Management seems to be waiting for literally every other AmLaw firm to raise first. This strategy is just postponing the inevitable, unless the firm is in dire straits or they don’t value their associates, in which case they should tell us that too. I don’t think they realize how much the delay is hurting associate morale.

This was followed a couple days later with:

Guys, seriously. This is getting ridiculous.

Well, don’t worry Pillsbury lawyers, the salary situation is not a reason to worry about the firm.

# Partners Need To Leave Stroock ASAP, Lest They Risk Their Profits
## Get out before the dissolution, Stroock partners, because your money depends on it.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 2, 2023 at 3:13 PMNovember 2, 2023 at 2:29 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/partners-need-to-leave-stroock-asap-lest-they-risk-their-profits/&text=Partners%20Need%20To%20Leave%20Stroock%20ASAP,%20Lest%20They%20Risk%20Their%20Profits)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/partners-need-to-leave-stroock-asap-lest-they-risk-their-profits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/partners-need-to-leave-stroock-asap-lest-they-risk-their-profits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

I read this email announcement from the firm leadership as giving everyone notice that they need to get out as quickly as possible so they’re not caught at the firm at the time it dissolves. If I were a partner at Stroock, even if I didn’t have a job lined up at a new firm, I would withdraw before the dissolution regardless.

— Professor [John Morley](https://law.yale.edu/john-d-morley) of Yale Law School, an expert in law firm failures, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/stroock-partners-profits-on-line-in-delicate-wind-down-process) on the advance notice that Stroock & Stroock & Lavan’s leaders gave employees, as a committee would soon be [dissolving the firm “at the appropriate time.”](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-to-dissolve-close-its-doors-after-nearly-150-years-in-business/) Partners especially need to heed Morley’s warning to get out, otherwise their ongoing fees may be at risk to creditors under the “unfinished business doctrine.”

# Vault Ranks The Best Law Firms For Diversity (2021)
## Did your law firm make the cut this time around?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 29, 2020 at 12:12 PMSeptember 29, 2020 at 11:46 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2021/&text=Vault%20Ranks%20The%20Best%20Law%20Firms%20For%20Diversity%20(2021))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-ranks-the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Over the course of September, Vault has rolled out a variety of law firm rankings — from the firms that are the [most prestigious](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-100-rankings-the-most-prestigious-law-firms-in-america-2021/) to the firms that offer the [best quality of life](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-quality-of-life-rankings-the-best-law-firms-to-work-for-in-america-2021/) to the firms with the [top-ranked practice areas in their region](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-rankings-top-law-firms-by-practice-area-and-region-2021/) to the [best midsized firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-quality-of-life-rankings-the-best-midsize-law-firms-to-work-for-2021/) — and there’s yet another important one that we’ll dive into today.

Money can buy prestige and can certainly improve your quality of life, but the diversity of your colleagues is worth more than what any salary scale can possibly pay.

In a companion ranking to the Vault 100, associates were asked to rank their own law firms based on categories most relevant to how the firm does at creating, maintaining, and fostering a diverse workforce, including diversity relating to racial minorities, women, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities. To create the overall Best 30 Firms for Diversity ranking, Vault averages the scores from all four ratings.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
There was a huge amount of movement in the Top 10 this year. Which firms made the cut? Without any further ado, here are the Top 10 Best Law Firms for Diversity based on Vault’s Annual Associate Survey for 2021:

1. [O’Melveny & Myers](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/omelveny-myers-llp) (no change)
2. [Constangy Brooks, Smith & Prophete](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/constangy-brooks-smith-prophete-llp) (+1)
3. [Ropes & Gray](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/ropes-gray-llp) (+2)
4. [Carlton Fields](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/carlton-fields-pa) (-2)
5. [Paul Hastings](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/paul-hastings-llp) (+12)
6. [Eversheds Sutherland (US)](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/eversheds-sutherland-us-llp) (+12)
7. [White & Case](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/white-case-llp) (-1)
8. [Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/orrick-herrington-sutcliffe-llp) (-4)
9. [Littler Mendelson](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/littler-mendelson-pc) (-1)
10. [Clifford Chance US](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/clifford-chance-us-llp) (+3)

It’s worth noting that O’Melveny once again swept Vault’s diversity rankings, but there are some other firms worth acknowledging here. Here’s some [additional commentary](https://www.vault.com/blogs/vaults-law-blog-legal-careers-and-industry-news/vaults-2021-law-firm-quality-of-life-diversity-and-summer-program-rankings-are-here) on that:

In this year’s 2021 diversity rankings, one firm stood out from the rest—for the second year in a row, O’Melveny took the crown as the No.1-ranked firm in every diversity category. The rankings also saw a particularly strong showing from five additional firms that placed in the top 10 in all five diversity categories: Carlton Fields, P.A.; Constangy Brooks, Smith & Prophete, LLP; Eversheds Sutherland; Ropes & Gray; and White & Case LLP.

# It's Not Your Imagination, There Are More Law Firm Mergers
## Bigger firms with a greater geographic reach are all the rage.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 4, 2023 at 5:46 PMOctober 4, 2023 at 4:37 PM
1

# Year-End And Special Bonuses To Covet At Another Biglaw Firm
## Lots of cash to dump on hardworking associates.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 15, 2021 at 4:27 PMDecember 27, 2021 at 12:56 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/covington-bonuses-21/&text=Year-End%20And%20Special%20Bonuses%20To%20Covet%20At%20Another%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/covington-bonuses-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/covington-bonuses-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If it seems like bonus announcements just won’t quit, that’s because there are a lot of Biglaw firms (and an increasing number of high-powered boutiques) that are eager to show their associates how much they are appreciated. And if in that process that can also prove that they can compete for the top legal talent during one of the busiest lateral markets on record, well, so much the better.

The latest firm to bring joy by announcing associate bonuses is Covington — a firm that took in $1,321,296,000 in gross revenue last year.

The good news for associates is that, yes, the firm will be matching both the year-end AND special bonuses that are making the rounds in Biglaw. Sure, that may not seem like a flex for a top 25 law firm, but Covington has, in the past, made some [missteps on that front](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/hope-for-fall-special-bonuses-is-fading-fast/). After [correcting course](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/top-30-am-law-firm-that-once-refused-special-bonuses-now-offers-them-as-part-of-year-end-bonus-scale/), it is nice to see them match all the money going to associates at competitor firms without much fuss.

The bonus scale at the firm is as follows:



You can read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/covington-bonuses-21/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Biglaw Partner Used To Think 2400 Hours Was The Bare Minimum -- Now She's Left The Practice Entirely
## Quinn Emanuel partner Jennifer Kash realized 3500 hours/year were taking a toll, so she walked away.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 5, 2019 at 3:15 PMNovember 7, 2019 at 11:06 AM
118
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/biglaw-partner-used-to-think-2400-hours-was-the-bare-minimum-now-shes-left-the-practice-entirely/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Used%20To%20Think%202400%20Hours%20Was%20The%20Bare%20Minimum%20—%20Now%20She’s%20Left%20The%20Practice%20Entirely)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/biglaw-partner-used-to-think-2400-hours-was-the-bare-minimum-now-shes-left-the-practice-entirely/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/biglaw-partner-used-to-think-2400-hours-was-the-bare-minimum-now-shes-left-the-practice-entirely/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in 2012, we wrote a story about Jennifer Kash, a Quinn Emanuel partner who sent around an email asking her associates to let her know their availability for more work. That’s not an uncommon ask in the Biglaw universe, but the takeaway from Kash’s email was that any associate billing under 2400 hours/year was still open to more work in the firm’s estimation:

In case you forgot: 5 is crazy busy, 4 is could do something but it would hurt and would have to be very small, 3 is you have some bandwidth and might be able to take on some more work, 2 is I could take on a bunch more work, my plate is not full, 1 is you need lots of work.

One further note, based on how busy everyone is if billing under 200 hours a month you are a 3.

At the time, we described Kash’s email as emblematic of the way firms see associates as consistently underutilized — a mindset that can level undue stress and potential burnout.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Today, Jennifer Kash would likely agree with that assessment. While associates working 2400+ and still getting assigned more work may sound miserable, Kash was billing 3500 hours at the time and only making due with healthy doses of Adderall. It’s easy to think of law firms as pyramid schemes because, in a sense, they are. But just because the associates grinding out hours at the base are whittled down to the partnership tier doesn’t mean the partners have stopped billing themselves. Many partners are juggling as much or more.

The former Quinn Emanuel San Francisco office chief is now living in the Caribbean running a non-profit called Virgin Independence, which helps transitional youth in finding jobs and training and working on a new program that invites attorneys to join her in St. Vincent and the Grenadines to get the support that lawyers rarely get while trying to manage their schedules.

[The Lawyer’s Escape Pod](https://thelawyersescapepod.podbean.com/) is an excellent podcast hosted by Megan Smiley that peeks outside the legal industry to show lawyers that there is, in fact, an escape route. Smiley [posted an interview with Kash](https://thelawyersescapepod.podbean.com/e/jen-kash-talksabouttheburnout-that-comes-with-3500-billable-hour-yearshow-she-left-the-firm-toget-healthy-and-startinghersecond-actin-the-caribbean/) where she opened up about her worldview as a partner and how she went from Biglaw big wig to living in the islands.

On the show, she describes the isolation that can form around partners in the Biglaw system:

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Law firm system not set up to support people at the top. Because we so assume once they get there and they have money and they’ve made it through the ranks of associates that there’s no longer going to be problems they need to address and there is. And the problem is there’s no place to go and no resources available to them because they don’t have any confidentiality and they need support in a way that’s embarrassing and that they’re not willing to maybe sometimes let their egos be set aside to address.

It’s a great way to close the loop on the article we posted seven years ago — time has a way of changing perspectives. Jennifer Kash wants lawyers to understand that taking care of themselves isn’t something they can just put off because the money’s good.

# Power Niche Marketing: The Great Marketing Revelation – It Is All Statistics
## This revelation should energize and excite you, as managing parter Bruce Stachenfeld explains.
By [Bruce Stachenfeld](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brucestachenfeld/)  
onMay 25, 2017 at 5:55 PMMay 25, 2017 at 3:58 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/power-niche-marketing-the-great-marketing-revelation-it-is-all-statistics/&text=Power%20Niche%20Marketing:%20The%20Great%20Marketing%20Revelation%20–%20It%20Is%20All%20Statistics)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/power-niche-marketing-the-great-marketing-revelation-it-is-all-statistics/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/power-niche-marketing-the-great-marketing-revelation-it-is-all-statistics/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Here is one of the great revelations of marketing. This is something I figured out over time and I am not sure exactly how. Certainly no one told me this and I didn’t read it anywhere. Maybe it is because I was a math major and just think about things mathematically. It is this:

Marketing is a game of pure statistics.

Ask anyone – I mean anyone – how they got their clients or their customers – especially their first clients or customers — and it is (almost) always completely serendipitous. It was a result of a series of events that could not be predicted or planned for.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
“I was picking up my three-year-old daughter from a play group because my nanny who usually does was sick, so there I was. I met the mom of my daughter’s friend, who happens to be a high-powered… and we were talking. I mentioned…. and then she said……. and the next thing you know, there I was…..”

It is all completely random. Indeed, if you make a marketing plan with ten target customers or clients, it almost always works out that your best shot fails and one you thought had no chance at all turns into a big win.

In the legal world, if you ask a big rainmaker for advice you will hear everything, and stated with incredible confidence too, as to how you get clients. You hear:

It is on the golf course – that’s where “real” business is done.
